subtitle: [Music]
hi everyone
my name is kathleen maca i'm a writer
who specializes in local history and
folklore from around the state of texas
thanks for joining us for this
installment of the tiny lecture series
from archaeology now
today we're going to be taking a look at
carriage stones and hitching posts
remnants from the horse and buggy days
and perfect examples
of how you might just be walking by
remnants of the past
every day galveston texas has one of the
largest concentrations of victorian
architecture in the united states
so it probably shouldn't come as a
surprise that other remnants of the era
have survived there as well
but sometimes they're hidden in plain
sight while walking along the streets of
galveston or
any historic neighborhood if you happen
to come across
two or three steps at the curb that
seemingly lead to nowhere
you've probably discovered an original
carriage block
also known as eppingstones these
architectural gems are a reminder of the
importance of horse-drawn transportation
during a previous era before the islands
mule-drawn trolleys were replaced by
electric ones in 1891
and ford's model t arrived on the scene
residents got around mostly by foot or
horse and buggy
the height of the carriage era lasted
from 1850 to 1910
a time when carriages were as common as
automobiles are today
carriage stones were blocks of granite
slate marble or concrete
that were placed near the edge of
streets in front of businesses
churches and the homes of middle and
upper class residents
the original carriage stone and hitching
post in front of the exquisite
seisheimer residents of galveston
can be spotted in this antique
photograph
victorian when men and women used the
blocks as a step
to assist in climbing in or out of their
carriages or on and off their horses
ladies who wore elaborate dresses found
them especially helpful
in boarding the carriage or mounting a
horse side saddle without scandalously
revealing their ankles by lifting their
skirts
the raised stones also prevented ladies
and gentlemen's shoes from sinking into
the mud on
rainy days the stones were usually cut
at local marble yards or monument
companies by stone cutters
the same way gravestones were sometimes
people used the terms
mounting block and carriage stone
interchangeably but there were distinct
differences
mounting blocks were simple in
appearance and resembled a large
stone or block of concrete designed
purely for function
and used for mounting horses they were
usually about
two by four foot rectangles and about 12
to 16 inches high
the extra height allowed the mounting
rider to take the strain off the stirrup
to keep the saddle from slipping it also
made the mounting process
easier on the horse's backs the 1893
james s
waters house on church street has an
especially beautiful example of a
mounting block
carved from a semi-circle of pink
granite with the family name inscribed
in elegant script
by contrast the simple block on broadway
impressed with the name
w.l moody jr belies the fact that this
was a carriage stop for the exquisite
1895 moody mansion the hand-carved
limestone block in front of the george
washington grover home on market street
may be one of the oldest on the island
it's now leveled with the grass and
sometimes covered by it
many of these stones are almost flush
with the pavement now because the street
levels were lower when they were
originally placed and the stones would
have originally sat much higher
a carriage step was a more elaborate
version of a mounting block that had two
or three steps
and it also might have had intricate
designs and architectural details
as just with about everything else of
that era the more elaborate styles were
a sign of status
in galveston the white marble carriage
step that lies on avenue n near 26th
street is inscribed with the name of a
long gone architectural treasure
the ursuline convent one of the most
attractive examples of this type of step
on the island
it's adorned on the sides with curving
scroll work
families could also add their names to
either mounting blocks
or carriage steps to help identify the
residences from the street
the daily name is still visible on the
block in front of their former home
many carriage blocks had hitching posts
nearby where a rider or driver could
dismount the horse or vehicle
and tie the reins attached to the
horse's bridle to the post with a
hitch which is a type of knot or tie
the post would then keep the horses from
running loose through the streets and
make sure they were there patiently
waiting when the rider returned
although most early wooden hitching
posts have decayed or been lost to
weather or other mishaps
galveston is fortunate to still have
dozens of cast iron versions
hundreds of iron foundries made
decorative hitching posts in the
19th century in the u.s but the three
biggest manufacturers
were j.w fisk and j.l mott of new york
city
and robert wooden company of
philadelphia the norwich iron foundry in
connecticut
and the starbuck foundry and w.j putnam
both of new york were also popular
the majority of hitching posts don't
have a maker's mark to identify their
origin
but those that do can usually be found
along the base or the side of the post
hitching posts became such an integrated
part of everyday lives that they were
even incorporated into sayings of the
day
like as cold as an iron hitching post as
sober as a hitching post
a little taller than a hitching post as
impassive as a hitching post
and as lively as a hitching post the
sayings bring a clear picture to mind
and
certainly aren't all complimentary as
the age of horse-drawn transportation
faded
mounting stones carriage steps and
hitching posts began to vanish from the
business districts and neighborhood
many were were removed during the
creation of paved streets or new
sidewalks
or were stolen to resell and some were
just removed because they were thought
to be outdated eyesores
later on the metal collections during
both world wars
caused the demise of some of the
remaining hitching posts which were
collected and melted down to aid war
efforts
those that remain lend an additional
charm to historic districts
and provide a glimpse of the everyday
life of previous generations
watch for them as you walk down streets
in older neighborhoods
a hitching post may have only the post
remaining missing its ornamental top
or even have been cut off level with the
curb leaving a mysterious
metal circle in the concrete some
carriage stones sit slightly askew from
the present day sidewalk
lay half buried in turf or even embedded
in the modern day sidewalk
a few have had the original family names
covered with cement or mosaics by more
recent
owners and others appear much as they
did in generations past
but a bit more worn finding examples of
carriage stones and hitching posts can
be a bit like a treasure hunt
but they all serve as an enchanting
reminder of the lifestyle of a bygone
era
so i encourage you to slow down on your
next walk through a historic
neighborhood
and look for things that remain from
long ago that give
clues to how our ancestors lived what
other items can you find
that reveal history in everyday places
